column2: a move that could help Republicans retain their majority in the U.S. Senate. ""I'll go home later this week. And I'll have some time with my family. And then
column3: if there's a change in our status
column4: I'll be sure to let everyone know
column5: the former Republican presidential candidate told reporters in the U.S. Capitol. Rubio
column7: first elected to the Senate in 2010
column8: announced his retirement from the Senate in March after losing Florida's presidential primary. But Senate Republican leader Mitch McConnell and others have been pressuring him to reconsider
column9: citing polling data showing him to be the only Republican who can win the election in Florida.

column1: Rubio confirmed a Politico report that he was urged to run for re-election on Sunday in Orlando
column3: by one of the Republicans contending for the seat
column4: his friend Lieutenant Governor Carlos Lopez-Cantera. The two men were in Orlando after the shooting that killed 49 people at a gay nightclub.Another Florida Republican hopeful

column1: Rubio must decide whether to seek re-election by June 24
column2: the filing deadline for Florida's August primary.

2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-pharmaceuticals-idUSKCN0Z22F1	Clinton outpaces rivals in drug company donations
By Ginger Gibson and Grant Smith
| WASHINGTON/NEW YORK

WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton has taken more money from employees of America's 15 biggest pharmaceuticals companies than all of the Republicans who attempted a run for the White House this year combined
column2: according to campaign finance disclosures.The donations
column3: which were nearly double those accepted by Democratic rival Bernie Sanders
column4: came even as the former senator and secretary of state vowed to curb price gouging in the industry if elected.Clinton's campaign took nearly $240
column5: 000 from employees of the industry between its launch and the end of April
column7: 000 for all of the Republicans together
column9: 700 for presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump
column10: according to the filings. The money
column11: a drop in the bucket of Clinton's nearly $190 million in overall individual contributions
column12: has tended to come from people in top jobs: 54 percent of the donors list their position as executive
column14: manager or lawyer. Donors and company officials contacted by Reuters declined to comment on the contributions.Industry insiders say the sector may be drawn to Clinton for a few reasons: She has a good chance of winning against Trump in November
column15: her policies are relatively transparent and predictable
column16: and she's more supportive of international trade than rivals.Many of the biggest pharmaceuticals companies are also headquartered in areas of the country that are more heavily populated by liberals
column17: like New Jersey and New York - another potential reason for the Clinton-heavy employee donations.

column1: (Trade) is
column3: an issue for the pharmaceutical industry. They all operate trans-nationally
column4: said Dan Mendelson
column5: president of Avalere Health
column6: a consulting firm that works with companies across the health sector.He added: ""We have very limited ability to predict what would happen in a Trump administration. We don't know the people
column7: we don't have a lot to go on.""Trump
column8: who largely self-funded his primary bid
column9: only recently began soliciting donations for the general election
column10: meaning his contributions from supporters in all industries are likely to rise in the coming months.

column1: Clinton tapped into widespread public frustration over soaring health costs this winter when she outlined a plan to curb drug price hikes and singled out pharmaceuticals company Valeant
column2: saying she would ""go after them"" if elected.Trump's campaign seized on Clinton's donations from the industry as proof that she would be unlikely to follow through. ""Hillary Clinton will be totally controlled by the special interests
column3: Trump spokeswoman Hope Hicks said.

column1: Clinton has rejected the idea.""Hillary Clinton has spent her career fighting to crack down on rising prescription drug prices and hold drug companies accountable
column2: spokesman Josh Schwerin said. Clinton's donations from drug companies have grown since the last time she ran
column4: but fall far short of her rival in that race
column5: President Barack Obama
column7: 000 in contributions from employees of pharmaceutical companies during the equivalent period of time.Clinton's total in this race so far
column9: beats the combined take in the 2012 election of Obama and Republican nominee Mitt Romney from employees of the industry of $170
column11: according to the filings. (Editing by Leslie Adler)"	['Clinton'

4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-fraud-idUSKCN0Z21TC	U.S. top court puts some limits on contractor fraud lawsuits	"
By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The U.S. Supreme Court on Thursday imposed some limits on the kind of fraud claims that can be brought against federal contractors in a case involving a suit against one of America's largest hospital operators over a woman's death at one of its facilities.But the 8-0 ruling was not the broad victory for business sought by the company
column3: and other healthcare providers fearful of suits under the U.S. False Claims Act
column4: which lets individuals make claims that the federal government has been defrauded.The justices threw out a 2015 appeals court ruling that had allowed the parents of Yarushka Rivera to sue Universal Health Services under the False Claims Act
column5: but sent the case back to a lower court
column6: meaning the suit could potentially still proceed.Rivera suffered a fatal seizure in 2009 at age 19 a mental health facility owned by the company in Lawrence
column7: Massachusetts. The lawsuit said the facility provided ""gravely inadequate treatment"" and used ""unsupervised and unqualified personnel.""The ruling represented a partial victory for the business community because it rejected the lower court's expansive view of a company's liability under the False Claims Act.

column1: Roy Englert
column3: Pennsylvania-based Universal Health Services' lawyer
column4: said he was pleased the justices threw out the appeals court ruling and set a ""new rigorous standard"" for determining if the claims can move forward.Rivera's parents
column5: Julio Escobar and Carmen Correa
column6: accused the company of defrauding the government because it was getting federal Medicaid funding to provide treatment to low-income people and did not comply with personnel regulations at the Lawrence facility.

column1: The ruling ""accepts the basic notion that fraudsters can't provide shoddy services to the government and expect payment without incurring significant liability
column3: the lawyer for Rivera's family.Businesses had hoped the justices would put more limits
column4: or disallow completely
column5: lawsuits based on a federal contractor's failure to meet certain legal or regulatory requirements not specifically outlined in a government contract. The court instead said such lawsuits can be filed as long as they are relevant to the government's decision to make the payment to the company.

column1: Justice Clarence Thomas
column3: said the parents ""may well have adequately pleaded a violation"" of the fraud law
column4: but added that the False Claims Act ""is not a means of imposing treble damages and other penalties for insignificant regulatory or contractual violations.""The Obama administration had backed the parents. (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley; Editing by Will Dunham)"	['Obama'
column5: 'Lawrence']	['healthcare']

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-idUSKCN0Z21KK	Clinton considering Warren

column1: WASHINGTON Hillary Clinton is considering U.S. Senator Elizabeth Warren for her running mate for the Democratic presidential ticket
column2: the Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday
column3: citing several people familiar with the process.Warren
column4: a leading progressive voice among Democrats
column5: is among those Democratic presidential candidate Clinton is vetting for the vice presidential position
column6: the newspaper reported. Clinton's rival Bernie Sanders is not
column7: it added. Sources told Reuters earlier this month that Warren
column9: is considering the potential role. Representatives for Clinton
column10: Sanders and Warren did not immediately reply to requests for comment on the report.Clinton is the Democratic Party's presumptive nominee for the Nov. 8 presidential election
column11: having won the last primary contest this week in the District of Columbia. Although Clinton and Sanders met this week
column12: the senator from Vermont does not plan to end his campaign or endorse Clinton in a video speech to supporters scheduled for later on Thursday

column1: While the search for a potential partner in the race is still in its early stages
column2: the Journal reported several Democrats said Clinton's campaign is looking at a number of potential candidates
column3: including Warren.Other prospective running mates include U.S. Labor Secretary Tom Perez and U.S. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro
column4: according to the report. Senators Tim Kaine of Virginia
column5: Sherrod Brown of Ohio and Cory Booker of New Jersey as well as U.S. Representatives Xavier Becerra of California and Tim Ryan of Ohio are also under consideration

column1: Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti is also a potential candidate
column2: it added. Warren threw her support behind Clinton last week as the former secretary of state moved her sights from the nominating contest toward a Nov. 8 match-up against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump.Warren could help Clinton win over Sanders supporters from the party's more liberal wing after a surprisingly protracted primary race. Sanders
column3: a self-described Democratic socialist
column4: has not yet dropped out.

column1: She also would give Clinton a vocal boost in her fight against Trump. Warren has called Trump a threat to the country and has vowed to keep lashing out at him.(This story has been refiled to remove superfluous word ""endorsed"" in paragraph nine.) (Writing by Susan Heavey; Editing by Lisa Von Ahn)"	['Sanders'

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-aflcio-idUSKCN0Z225A	Labor powerhouse AFL-CIO backs Clinton
By Kouichi Shirayanagi
The largest labor federation in the United States
column3: endorsed Hillary Clinton for president on Thursday
column4: vowing to throw the full weight of more than 50 unions representing 12.5 million members behind the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee.     ""Hillary Clinton is a proven leader who shares our values
column5: AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka said in a statement. ""We will run a sophisticated
column6: targeted ground campaign. And with the dire consequences Donald Trump poses for America's working families
column7: it has to be."" While the federation generally does not endorse a Democratic candidate until there is an official nominee
column8: Trumka has warned for months that he believes Republican presumptive nominee Donald Trump would be disastrous for working people if elected.

column1: After the endorsement
column2: Clinton pledged to spend more on public infrastructure and to fight to improve schools. She vowed to increase the federal minimum wage
column3: offer paid family leave and ensure that women receive equal pay.""As president
column4: I will stand proudly with the AFL-CIO and fight to protect the rights and values that helped build the mighty American middle class. Workers will always have a seat at the table and a champion in the White House
column5: Clinton said in a statement.

column1: The AFL-CIO has already run digital ads criticizing Trump's candidacy and will now work to boost Clinton's campaign on the ground. Working America
column2: one AFL-CIO affiliate that deals with nonunion workers
column3: already has teams in crucial so-called battleground states.In response to the federation's endorsement of Clinton
column4: Trump's campaign said the AFL-CIO no longer represents the interests of American workers. ""I will fight harder for American workers than anyone ever has
column5: Trump said in a statement.

column1: Trump attacked Clinton for supporting free trade agreements and said he would win a majority of votes from U.S. union families. (Reporting by Kouichi Shirayanagi and Amanda Becker; Editing by Susan Heavey

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-hack-idUSKCN0Z209Q	'Lone hacker' claims responsibility for cyber attack on Democrats	"
A ""lone hacker"" has taken responsibility for a cyber attack on the U.S. Democratic National Committee
column2: which the DNC and a cyber-security firm have blamed on the Russian government.The DNC and cyber firm CrowdStrike disclosed the attack on Tuesday
column3: saying that hackers working for Russia broke into the DNC's computer network
column4: spied on internal communications and stole research on presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump.A Russian government spokesman responded by saying that Moscow had not been involved.On Wednesday
column5: an individual using the moniker Guccifer 2.0 took responsibility for the attack in a post on the blogging site WordPress.com
column6: saying the DNC was ""hacked by a lone hacker.""

column1: The DNC did not respond to a request for comment late on Wednesday evening on Guccifer 2.0's claim. CrowdStrike said it stands by findings that the Russian government was behind the attacks. Guccifer 2.0's blog includes images of documents it claims were stolen from DNC servers
column3: which was dated Dec. 19
column4: and spreadsheets purportedly containing information about party donors.

column1: Reuters was unable to verify the authenticity of the documents
column2: which the blog said were among ""thousands of files and mails"" removed from DNC servers that would soon be published on WikiLeaks. CrowdStrike issued a statement saying it ""stands fully by its analysis"" that two groups affiliated with Russian intelligence were discovered in the DNC's network last month.

column1: The company said it was reviewing the documents published by Guccifer 2.0 to determine whether they were authentic.  (Reporting by Jim Finkle. Additional reporting by Emily Stephenson; Editing by Nick Macfie)"	['Trump']	[]

column1: By Dave McKinney and Karen Pierog
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO Illinois will sell $550 million of bonds on Thursday but lacks authority from the state legislature to spend all of the proceeds due to an ongoing budget impasse.""The General Assembly needs to grant appropriation authority to fully expend the proceeds from the bond sale
column2: although existing FY16 appropriations could be used to expend a portion of them
column3: Catherine Kelly
column4: a spokeswoman for Governor Bruce Rauner
column5: said on Wednesday.Her statement followed a news conference earlier on Wednesday with the Republican governor and his transportation department head
column6: who warned of the imminent shutdown of hundreds of construction projects if the Democrat-controlled legislature does not approve Rauner's temporary budget plan.All but $20 million of the state's general obligation bond issue is earmarked for mass transit and road construction projects.The odd timing of the announcement on the eve of the state bond sale handed Rauner's Democratic rivals in the state legislature fodder to question the first-term governor's actions.

column1: We're hoping none of his activities or staff work is going to drive up borrowing costs like it did for the Chicago Public Schools in February
column3: spokesman for Democratic House Speaker Michael Madigan.The school district delayed
column4: then downsized its bond sale
column5: after Rauner threatened a state takeover of CPS and said the system was headed for bankruptcy
column6: comments Chicago Mayor Rahm Emanuel called ""shameful"" because of their possible impact on the bond sale.

column1: Rauner on Wednesday pleaded with Democratic lawmakers to return to session to pass a spending plan that would keep the state operating until January and fully fund K-12 schools.""Allowing the crisis to continue is wrong
column3: referring to the ongoing impasse that has left Illinois as the only state without a fiscal 2016 budget.Illinois has been dependent on court orders and a muddle of ongoing and stopgap appropriations to continue operating and lawmakers have not reached any agreement on a budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

column1: The state's GO bonds trade at wide spreads over Municipal Market Data's benchmark triple-A yield scale. But Illinois' upcoming debt issue will likely benefit from yields in the municipal market that are at or near record lows as cash-heavy investors chase scarce supply of bonds issued by states
column3: schools and other issuers.Illinois' already low credit ratings were downgraded last week ahead of the sale.  (Editing by Matthew Lewis and Jacqueline Wong)"	['Rauner'

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-watchlists-factbox-idUSKCN0Z127D	Factbox: Eyes on U.S. terrorism watchlists after Orlando shootings	"
By Julia Edwards
As facts emerge about Omar Mateen
column2: the gunman who killed 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando
column3: Florida
column4: on Sunday
column5: questions have arisen about how well-known he was to U.S. intelligence agencies.Federal Bureau of Investigation Director James Comey said on Monday that Mateen was on a watchlist between May 2013 and March 2014 while he was under investigation after claiming a connection to or support for multiple Islamist extremist groups
column8: al-Nusra and Islamic State.The FBI maintains three watchlists and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence runs one database. People are placed on a watchlist according to the threat level they are believed to pose. Comey did not specify which watchlist named Mateen. Democratic presidential candidate Hilary Clinton has supported stricter gun laws and said on Monday she would push for laws that would prevent people on a no-fly list from buying guns.

column1: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump
column3: said he would meet with the leading U.S. gun rights group about preventing people on a government watchlist from buying guns.The U.S. government maintains the following databases:Terrorist Watchlist or Terrorist Screening Database (about 420
column4: 000 names): Established after the Sept. 11
column7: the Terrorist Watchlist is intended ""to positively identify known or suspected terrorists trying to obtain visas
column10: or engage in other activity."" Prior to 2001
column11: intelligence agencies maintained dozens of individual lists. The Terrorist Watchlist is run by the FBI's Terrorist Screening Center with the goal of consolidating the U.S. government's watchlists into a single database.

column1: No-Fly List (about 16
column2: 000 names): A subset of the Terrorist Screening Database
column3: the No-Fly List prohibits people known or suspected of terrorism from boarding a plane that departs from or arrives in the United States.  Selectee List (about 16
column4: 000 names): A subset of the Terrorist Watchlist
column5: the Selectee List includes individuals who are permitted to fly
column6: but receive more intensive screening. In addition to the thousands of records updated daily from federal
column8: the Selectee List provides an additional level of screening for individuals thought to present a greater threat.

column1: Terrorist Identities Datamart Environment
column3: database (about 1.1 million names): Run by the National Counterterrorism Center
column4: part of the Office of the National Director of Intelligence
column5: the TIDE Database shares information with the FBI's watchlists. As of December 2013
column8: 000 of them U.S. citizens. Unlike the FBI's database
column9: TIDE is viewable only by counterterrorism professionals in the U.S. intelligence community and is not shared with local law enforcement. Federal agencies propose people for inclusion on the TIDE database based on an evaluation of the threat they pose. Reasons someone may be added to the TIDE database include committing terrorist activity
column10: preparing or planning a terrorist activity or providing support
column12: for a terrorist organization. (Reporting by Julia Edwards in Washington; Editing by Toni Reinhold and Peter Cooney)"	['Clinton']	['guns'
